provenance.name: Goyder Collection, Fitzwilliam Museum
provenance.note: Early history unknown; offered by the dealer James Tregaskis, undated *Caxton Head Catalogue* (c. 1893?), item 104, titled "The Judgment of a Saint" (£8.8s.); sold Sotheby's, 11 May 1895, lot 155, titled "The Almighty appearing to Moses" (£9 to Sidney Morse); wife of Sidney Morse, probably by inheritance in 1929; offered "by Order of the Executors of Mrs. J[uliet]. M. Morse," Christie's, 19 March 1937, lot 47, titled "Elijah and Elisha" (bought-in at £52.5s.); sold "by order of the Executors of Mrs. Sydney Morse," Christie's, 25 June 1937, lot 95, titled "Elijah and Elisha" (£105 to the dealer "Dunn" acting for George Goyder); on deposit by the estate of George Goyder (1908-97) at the Fitzwilliam Museum since 1998.

desc.objtitle: Elijah and the Chariot of Fire Elijah and Elisha God Judging Adam The Almighty Appearing to Moses The Judgment of a Saint" Object 1 (Butlin 258)

objnote.p: Butlin 258 titles the work *God Judging Adam* because it is the model for the 1795 large color printed drawing *God Judging Adam* and dates the work to c. 1790-93. We believe that the subject is actually Elijah and the chariot of fire, or Elijah and Elisha, as earlier titles indicate (see 2 Kings 2:11-12 and the note on provenance). We also believe, on stylistic grounds, that this water color dates from a slightly earlier period, c. 1788-89.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is based on 2 Kings 2:11-12. Elijah, who is old, gowned, bearded and has long hair, sits on a chariot (?) made of clouds or smoke and drawn by two horses. Elisha, likewise old, gowned, bearded, and with long hair stands before him bowing slightly, likely in a gesture of prayer and/or submission. Both of Elijah's hands rest on either an open book or two tablets on his lap. Elijah is holding the horses' reins in his left hand.

component.illusobjdesc: Elijah sits on a chariot (?) made of clouds or smoke. He is bearded, gowned, old, and has long hair. He faces to the left looking at Elisha. Elijah may also be using his left hand to hold the horses' reins. Both of Elijah's hands rest on either an open book or two tablets on his lap.
Either an open book or two tablets (of laws?) rests on Elijah’s lap.
Elijah is holding the reins of the horses in his left hand.
Elijah sits on a chariot made of clouds or smoke.
Two horses, facing left, pull the chariot upon which Elijah sits. Both horses stride to the left with their front left hooves and their back right hooves. The reins extend into Elijah's left hand.
Elisha, old, gowned, bearded, and with long hair stands before Elijah bowing slightly, likely in a gesture of prayer and/or submission. Elisha's bare right foot is visible outside of his gown.
